# _Bronze Fonz_

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

Bronze Fonz  
---  
[![SawyerBronzeFonz2008.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b9/SawyerBronzeFonz2008.jpg/200px-
SawyerBronzeFonz2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:SawyerBronzeFonz2008.jpg)  
Artist | [Gerald P. Sawyer](/w/index.php?title=Gerald_P._Sawyer&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gerald P. Sawyer \(page does not exist\)")  
Year | 2008 (2008)  
Dimensions | 170 cm (65 in)  
Location | [Milwaukee](/wiki/Milwaukee "Milwaukee")  
[Coordinates](/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system "Geographic coordinate system") | [43°2′25.63″N 87°54′40.10″W﻿ / ﻿43.0404528°N 87.9111389°W﻿ / 43.0404528; -87.9111389](//tools.wmflabs.org/geohack/geohack.php?pagename=Bronze_Fonz&params=43_2_25.63_N_87_54_40.10_W_region:US_type:landmark)  
Owner | Visit Milwaukee  
  
The _**Bronze Fonz**_ is a public artwork by [American](/wiki/United_States
"United States") artist [Gerald P.
Sawyer](/w/index.php?title=Gerald_P._Sawyer&action=edit&redlink=1 "Gerald P.
Sawyer \(page does not exist\)") located on the [Milwaukee
Riverwalk](/wiki/Milwaukee_Riverwalk "Milwaukee Riverwalk") just south of
Wells Street in downtown [Milwaukee](/wiki/Milwaukee "Milwaukee"),
[Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin "Wisconsin"). The _Bronze Fonz_ depicts [Henry
Winkler](/wiki/Henry_Winkler "Henry Winkler") as the _[Happy
Days](/wiki/Happy_Days "Happy Days")_ TV show character Arthur Fonzarelli,
also known as [the Fonz](/wiki/Fonzie "Fonzie").[1] Fonzie stands in his
typical costume, which consists of a leather jacket and jeans. He is giving a
two-handed [thumbs up](/wiki/Thumbs_signal "Thumbs signal").

## Description[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bronze_Fonz&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Description")]

The _Bronze Fonz_ is made of [bronze](/wiki/Bronze "Bronze"). The sculpture
depicts Henry Winkler, the actor who played Fonz in the show _Happy Days_.
_Happy Days_ , which aired in the 1970s, was a sitcom about a family in
1950s/1960s Milwaukee. Arthur Fonzarelli (also known as "Fonzie" or "The
Fonz"), wears a leather jacket and jeans. He is giving a two handed thumbs up,
a gesture he often made in _Happy Days_. The inscription lists all of the
donors that made the _Bronze Fonz_ possible.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bronze_Fonz&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: History")]

The artwork was created with the purpose of bringing tourism and new
businesses to Milwaukee. Other places in the United States have erected
statues portraying 1950s and 1960s television characters. Examples include:
Mary Tyler Moore as Mary Richards from _[The Mary Tyler Moore
Show](/wiki/The_Mary_Tyler_Moore_Show "The Mary Tyler Moore Show")_ in
Minneapolis and Jackie Gleason as Ralph Kramden from _[The
Honeymooners](/wiki/The_Honeymooners "The Honeymooners")_ outside the [Port
Authority Bus Terminal](/wiki/Port_Authority_Bus_Terminal "Port Authority Bus
Terminal") in Manhattan. The tourism group Visit Milwaukee raised over
US$85,000 to commission the _Bronze Fonz_. The popular sculpture was unveiled
on August 18, 2008. Most of the _Happy Days_ cast, including [Henry
Winkler](/wiki/Henry_Winkler "Henry Winkler") (Fonzie) [Marion
Ross](/wiki/Marion_Ross "Marion Ross") (Mrs. Cunningham), [Tom
Bosley](/wiki/Tom_Bosley "Tom Bosley") (Mr. Cunningham), [Erin
Moran](/wiki/Erin_Moran "Erin Moran") (Joanie), [Don Most](/wiki/Don_Most "Don
Most") (Ralph Malph), and [Anson Williams](/wiki/Anson_Williams "Anson
Williams") (Potsie), attended the dedication ceremony. Henry Winkler stated
that the statue was "unbelievable".[2]

### Opposition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bronze_Fonz&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Opposition")]

Mike Brenner, then a local gallery owner and executive director of Milwaukee
Artist Resource Network (MARN), objected to the statue, which was originally
planned to be located at the intersection of Wisconsin and Water Streets, a
prominent downtown site. He threatened to close his gallery, Hotcakes, and
resign as executive director of MARN if "that stupid Fonzie sculpture" was
erected there.[3] Brenner received death threats for voicing against the
Bronze Fonz and posted several on his web site.[4] The CEO of the [Milwaukee
Art Museum](/wiki/Milwaukee_Art_Museum "Milwaukee Art Museum"), David Gordon,
along with Mary-Louise Schumacher, arts critic for the _[Milwaukee Journal
Sentinel](/wiki/Milwaukee_Journal_Sentinel "Milwaukee Journal Sentinel")_ ,
and other Milwaukee arts dignitaries also opposed the statue. It was
eventually relocated to the Riverwalk site. Brenner indeed closed Hotcakes
Gallery in May 2008, and has since become a [microbrewer](/wiki/Microbrewery
"Microbrewery"), remaining in Milwaukee.[5][6]

### Acquisition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bronze_Fonz&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Acquisition")]

The piece was commissioned by Visit Milwaukee, a non-profit group that works
toward making Milwaukee a place for tourism and interest. Visit Milwaukee
raised $85,000 to commission the statue.[1]

## In popular
culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Bronze_Fonz&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: In popular culture")]

The statue is referenced in the lyrics of the 2014 song "Milwaukee" by [The
Both](/wiki/The_Both "The Both").[7] The song, which recounted the local
origin of the collaboration between the duo of [Aimee Mann](/wiki/Aimee_Mann
"Aimee Mann") and [Ted Leo](/wiki/Ted_Leo "Ted Leo"), was the first single
from their [self-titled debut album](/wiki/The_Both "The Both").[8]

Mentioned in the cozy mystery novel - In the Drink by Allyson K. Abbott.
